MonteCarloAI.java

00001 import java.util.Random;
00003 
00017 public class MonteCarloAI extends AIModule
00018 {
00020         private final Random r = new Random(System.currentTimeMillis());
00022         private int[] moves;
00023 
00025         @Override
00026         public void getNextMove(final GameStateModule state)
00027         {
00028                 // Set up the legal moves buffer.  We use only one buffer repeatedly to
00029                 // avoid needless memory allocations.
00030                 moves = new int[state.getWidth()];
00031 
00032                 // Default to choosing the first column (should be fixed after a few rounds)
00033                 chosenMove = 0;
00034 
00035                 // Cache our index.
00036                 final int ourPlayer = state.getActivePlayer();
00037 
00038                 // Create value array and set all illegal moves to minimum value.
00039                 // This will be filled in using results from random games:
00040                 // +1 point for each win
00041                 // +0 point for each draw
00042                 // -1 point for each loss.
00043                 // We also initialize all illegal moves to -Integer.MAX_VALUE.  We could also
00044                 // have used Integer.MIN_VALUE, but this is a "weird number" because
00045                 // -Integer.MIN_VALUE == Integer.MIN_VALUE.
00046                 int[] values = new int[state.getWidth()];
00047                 for(int i = 0; i < values.length; ++i)
00048                         if(!state.canMakeMove(i))
00049                                 values[i] = -Integer.MAX_VALUE;
00050 
00051                 // Start simulating games! Continue until told to stop.
00052                 while(!terminate)
00053                 {
00054                         final int move = getMove(state);
00055                         state.makeMove(move);
00056                         updateGuess(ourPlayer, playRandomGame(state), values, move);
00057                         state.unMakeMove();
00058                 }
00059         }
00060 
00062 
00068         private int getMove(final GameStateModule state)
00069         {
00070                 // Fill in what moves are legal.
00071                 int numLegalMoves = 0;
00072                 for(int i = 0; i < state.getWidth(); ++i)
00073                         if(state.canMakeMove(i))
00074                                 moves[numLegalMoves++] = i;
00075 
00076                 // Pick one randomly.
00077                 final int n = r.nextInt(numLegalMoves);
00078                 return moves[n];
00079         }
00080 
00081         // Given the result of the last game, update our chosen move.
00092         private void updateGuess(final int ourPlayer, final int result, int[] values, int move)
00093         {
00094                 // On a draw, we can skip making changes.
00095                 if(result == 0)
00096                         return;
00097 
00098                 // Update the expected value of this move depending on whether we win or lose.
00099                 values[move] += (result == ourPlayer ? 1 : -1);
00100 
00101                 // Update the move to be the best known move.  This is necessary since we need
00102                 // to have the best move available at all times because we run forever.
00103                 for(int i = 0; i < values.length; ++i)
00104                         if(values[i] > values[chosenMove])
00105                                 chosenMove = i;
00106         }
00107 
00109 
00117         private int playRandomGame(final GameStateModule state)
00118         {
00119                 // Duplicate the state to prevent changes from propagating.
00120                 final GameStateModule game = state.copy();
00121                 while(!game.isGameOver())
00122                         game.makeMove(getMove(game));
00123 
00124                 // It's over!  Return who won.
00125                 return game.getWinner();
00126         }
00127 }
